description: From Middle English consanguinytee, consanguinite, consanguinyte, from Old French consanguinité and Latin cōnsanguinitātem, accusative of Latin cōnsanguinitās, from cōnsanguineus, from Latin com- (“together”) + sanguineus (“of or pertaining to blood”), from Latin sanguis (“blood”).

entries.meaning: A consanguineous or family relationship through parentage or descent. A blood relationship.
examples: They too have been deaf to the voice of justice and of consanguinity.
